narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Social Media Corpus + Instagram RCT Survey + User Analytics Study

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer:
The project "NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Social Media Corpus + Instagram RCT Survey + User Analytics Study" is anticipated to generate a variety of scientific data, including but not limited to:
- Social media posts and comments collected via a third-party vendor
- Participant survey responses
- Program monitoring and engagement analytics
- Derived coded and cleaned datasets from the aforementioned data sources
- Analysis scripts used for data processing and analysis
- Documentation such as codebooks, data dictionaries, instruments, and README files

The volume of data generated is expected to depend on the size of the social media corpus collected and the amount of retained analytics. However, it's estimated that the total dataset will be substantial due to the comprehensive nature of social media and survey data.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer:
This project aims to preserve and share de-identified datasets, derived variables, and documentation to support reproducibility and facilitate future research in similar areas. The scientific data to be preserved and shared include:
- De-identified participant survey responses
- Derived coded and cleaned datasets from social media and analytics data
- Analysis scripts and associated documentation

The rationale for sharing these data is to maximize the utility of the research findings, promote transparency, and enable other researchers to build upon or verify our results. Sharing data also aligns with the principles of open science and contributes to the advancement of knowledge in the field.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate the interpretation and reuse of the scientific data, the following metadata and documentation will be made accessible:
- Study protocols outlining data collection methods and instruments
- Data collection instruments (e.g., survey questionnaires)
- Data dictionaries describing variables and their formats within datasets
- Codebooks detailing coding schemes used for derived variables
- README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, content, and any specific instructions for use
- Analysis scripts used to generate results

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software may be necessary to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. Specifically:
- Statistical analysis software (e.g., R, Python libraries like Pandas and NumPy) will be required for analyzing the datasets.
- Data manipulation and cleaning may involve using specific libraries or packages within these software environments.
- Access to certain data visualization tools might also be beneficial but not strictly necessary.

These tools are widely available in academic and research settings, and detailed instructions on how to access and use them will be provided in the associated documentation.

To ensure interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied. The project will adhere to:
- Data documentation standards (e.g., Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) for describing survey and social media datasets)
- Metadata standards (e.g., Dublin Core for general metadata elements)
- For statistical analysis and data manipulation, adherence to community-accepted formats such as CSV for tabular data and JSON for structured data will facilitate sharing and reuse.

These standards are chosen for their widespread adoption in the research community and their ability to promote data sharing and collaboration. If applicable, the project may also explore emerging standards in social media data analysis to stay aligned with best practices in the field.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and associated metadata from this project will be archived in a designated NIH-approved repository. The specific repository will be selected based on its suitability for hosting the types of data generated (e.g., social media datasets, survey responses) and its compliance with NIH guidelines for data sharing.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure that the scientific data are findable and identifiable, they will be assigned a persistent unique identifier (e.g., DOI) upon deposition into the repository. This identifier will enable easy citation and access to the dataset. Additionally, standard indexing tools and metadata descriptors will be used to facilitate discovery through search interfaces.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings from the project or at the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data are expected to remain accessible for a minimum of 10 years following the completion of the project to allow for long-term research utility and verification of results.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer:
Given that this project involves human subjects and the collection of social media data, several factors will affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data. These include:
- Informed consent agreements that specify how participant data can be shared and used
- Privacy and confidentiality protections to ensure that direct identifiers are not included in shared datasets
- Potential restrictions on the use of raw social media content due to vendor terms or privacy considerations

These limitations are necessary to protect the rights and privacy of human research participants and comply with applicable laws and regulations.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain components of the scientific data may be controlled, particularly for datasets that contain potentially sensitive information or are restricted by vendor agreements. In such cases, access will be provided through a controlled mechanism, such as a data request process that requires approval from the project's data management team.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants:
- Participant data will be de-identified before sharing.
- Direct identifiers will not be included in shared datasets.
- Raw social media content will not be shared when restricted by vendor terms or privacy considerations; instead, derived/coded data will be shared.
- Informed consent documents will clearly describe the collection, confidentiality protections, and potential sharing of de-identified data.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer:
Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. The oversight process will include:
- Regular review of data management practices to ensure adherence to the plan
- Annual updates to the data management plan as necessary, reflecting any changes in project protocols or data sharing requirements
- Coordination with the institutional review board (IRB) to ensure that human subjects protections are maintained throughout the data sharing process

The PI and designated research staff will be responsible for ensuring that all aspects of the plan are implemented correctly and that any issues or concerns related to data management and sharing are addressed promptly.
